items.title: What is Islam?
items.description: Islam is the life system ordained by Allah, sent for the welfare of humanity.

items.title: Six Pillars of Iman
items.description: Belief in Allah, angels, holy books, prophets, the Day of Judgment, and divine decree is called Iman.

items.title: Five Pillars of Islam
items.description: Shahada (faith), Salah (prayer), Sawm (fasting), Zakat (charity), and Hajj (pilgrimage) are the five fundamental pillars of Islam.

items.title: Tawheed
items.description: Belief in the Oneness of Allah and worshipping Him alone is called Tawheed.

items.title: Shirk
items.description: Associating partners with Allah is called Shirk, which is the gravest sin.

items.title: Good Deeds and Sins
items.description: Good deeds are performed for Allah's pleasure, while sins are actions prohibited by Allah.

items.title: Belief in God and the Hereafter
items.description: Belief in Allah and life after death is part of Iman.

items.title: Purpose of Islam
items.description: To guide humanity towards a righteous life and ensure worship of Allah.

items.title: Importance of Salah
items.description: Salah is a major pillar of Islam and a primary means of worship.

items.title: Purpose of Fasting
items.description: Fasting is observed to gain Allah's pleasure and for self-purification.

items.title: Importance of Zakat
items.description: Zakat purifies wealth and helps the needy in society.

items.title: Importance of Hajj
items.description: Performing Hajj once in a lifetime is obligatory for eligible Muslims.

items.title: History of Quran Revelation
items.description: The Quran was revealed gradually to Prophet Muhammad ﷺ over 23 years.

items.title: Makki and Madani Surahs
items.description: Surahs revealed before Hijrah are Makki, and those revealed after are Madani.

items.title: Division of the Quran
items.description: The Quran is divided into Ayahs, Surahs, and Juz.

items.title: Memorizing the Quran
items.description: Hifz (memorization) of the Quran is a noble act and earns Allah's pleasure.

items.title: Recitation with Tajweed
items.description: Reciting the Quran with proper pronunciation and rules is required.

items.title: Importance of Surah Al-Fatiha
items.description: It is the opening Surah and is essential in every Salah.

items.title: Lessons from Surah Al-Baqarah
items.description: Guides humanity in morality, discipline, and strengthening faith.

items.title: Relationship between Quran and Hadith
items.description: The Quran is the main text, and Hadith explains its teachings and implementation.

items.title: Virtue of Quran Recitation
items.description: Reciting the Quran increases nearness to Allah and forgives sins.

items.title: Language of the Quran
items.description: The Quran was revealed in Arabic.

items.title: Applying Quranic Teachings
items.description: Implementing moral and ethical teachings in daily life is essential.

items.title: Qiyamul Layl
items.description: Praying at night and reciting Quran is Sunnah and highly rewarding.

items.title: What is Hadith?
items.description: Hadith is the sayings, actions, and approvals of Prophet Muhammad ﷺ.

items.title: Types of Hadith
items.description: Hadith is classified as Sahih (authentic), Hasan (good), and Da'if (weak).

items.title: Importance of Sahih Hadith
items.description: Authentic Hadith with a reliable chain is accepted as a source of Islamic law.

items.title: Purpose of Hadith
items.description: To guide people towards Islamic way of life and moral conduct.

items.title: Seerah of the Prophet
items.description: The life of Prophet ﷺ explained through Quran and Hadith.

items.title: Hadith and Fatwa
items.description: Hadith serves as a source of legal rulings and moral guidance.

items.title: Rules for Reading Hadith
items.description: Reading Hadith with belief and attention improves moral character.

items.title: Chain of Hadith (Sanad)
items.description: A Hadith with a reliable chain is accepted.

items.title: Ethical Lessons in Hadith
items.description: Teaches humanity, patience, and honesty.

items.title: Hadith on Duas and Sacrifice
items.description: Emphasizes the importance of supplication and worship in life.

items.title: Importance of Salah
items.description: Salah is a pillar of Islam and a key means to enter Paradise.

items.title: Causes of Salah Invalidity
items.description: Talking, laughing, or intentional loss of ablution invalidates Salah.

items.title: Fard and Sunnah Prayers
items.description: Fard prayers are obligatory, Sunnah are recommended. Missing Fard is sinful.

items.title: Jumu'ah Prayer
items.description: Friday congregational prayer is obligatory and should be performed in the mosque.

items.title: Nafl (Optional) Prayers
items.description: Optional prayers increase reward and nearness to Allah.

items.title: Salah Timings
items.description: Prayers must be performed at their specified times.

items.title: Salat al-Tasbih
items.description: A Sunnah prayer with great reward.

items.title: Taraweeh Prayer
items.description: Night prayer in Ramadan as part of Qiyamul Layl.

items.title: Essential Surahs for Salah
items.description: Surah Al-Fatiha is Fard, other Surahs are Sunnah.

items.title: Ending Salah
items.description: Salah is concluded by saying Salaam.

items.title: Daily Life Duas
items.description: Prophet ﷺ taught supplications for sleeping, eating, traveling, and other activities.

items.title: Morning and Evening Dhikr
items.description: Reciting these protects one under Allah's care.

items.title: Dua for Fasting
items.description: Recited before starting and when breaking the fast.

items.title: Travel Dua
items.description: Supplication for safety before traveling.

items.title: Importance of Dhikr
items.description: Calms the heart and keeps one in remembrance of Allah.

items.title: Accepted Duas
items.description: Duas offered with sincerity and Taqwa are quickly accepted.

items.title: Salat al-Hajah
items.description: Prayer and supplication for urgent needs.

items.title: Masnoon Duas
items.description: Supplications taught by the Prophet ﷺ as Sunnah.

items.title: Dua before Starting Work
items.description: Supplication seeking Allah’s help before important tasks.

items.title: Dua at Time of Death
items.description: Supplication and piety at the time of death.

items.title: Biography of Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
items.description: Born in 570 CE in Makkah, he was a mercy for mankind.

items.title: The Four Caliphs
items.description: Abu Bakr, Umar, Uthman, and Ali (RA) were exemplary rulers of Islam.

items.title: Importance of Hijrah
items.description: Migration from Makkah to Madinah established the Islamic community.

items.title: Battle of Badr
items.description: The first major military victory in Islamic history.

items.title: Unity of the Ummah
items.description: Unity and cooperation are essential in Islamic history.

items.title: Achievements of Caliph Ali (RA)
items.description: Justice and adherence to Islamic principles in governance.

items.title: Hijri Calendar
items.description: Based on the Prophet’s ﷺ migration (Hijrah) from Makkah to Madinah.

items.title: History of Khilafat
items.description: Leadership and reigns of the four rightly-guided Caliphs.

items.title: Spread of Islam
items.description: Through the efforts of the Prophet ﷺ and Sahabah, Islam reached many lands.

items.title: History of Masjid al-Madina
items.description: The first mosque established by the Prophet ﷺ.

items.title: Is listening to music Haram?
items.description: According to most scholars, listening to musical instruments and songs is Haram.

items.title: Is keeping a beard obligatory?
items.description: According to many scholars, keeping a beard is Wajib (required).

items.title: Marriage age in Islam
items.description: Marriage age depends on physical and mental maturity.

items.title: When is Jumu’ah prayer obligatory?
items.description: Friday prayer is obligatory at the designated time.

items.title: How much Zakat to pay?
items.description: 2.5% of wealth exceeding the Nisab threshold annually is required.

items.title: Is fasting obligatory?
items.description: Fasting is obligatory for those who are physically and mentally able.

items.title: Importance of good deeds
items.description: Good deeds increase reward and earn Allah's pleasure.

items.title: Forgiveness of sins
items.description: Allah forgives sins for those who sincerely repent.

items.title: Social responsibilities of Muslims
items.description: Helping the poor, justice, and honesty are essential.

items.title: Following the Sunnah of the Prophet ﷺ
items.description: Following the Prophet's ﷺ life increases worship and righteousness.
